Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 14: The events which motivated the prince to renounce the world
A short while later, the Bodhisattva said to his equerry: “Quick, Chandaka (Mdun pa), saddle up my stallion, we'll go to the pleasure gardens!”
Manual - English: There is a scene of death, illness, old age, and renunciation.

Sun of Faith - English: The boy swiftly obeyed.
At the hour agreed upon, they climbed into the carriage and went off.
On their way, the young people met a bent old man who was hobbling along with the help of a cane.
“Chandaka, what has happened to this man?” wondered Siddhartha.
“Prince,” replied the equerry, “he is old. He is not long for this life. In a short while, he will die.”
“Will I too be subject to this occurrence?”
“Of course. No one, not even a prince can escape the process of ageing.”
“Turn round! Back to the palace!”
Once more in his chamber, the prince lost himself in his thoughts. “So. Everyone lives at the mercy of old age.” He felt stunned.
The king probed Chandaka to find out if the prince had enjoyed his visit to the pleasure gardens
and the latter recounted all that had occurred.
The king grew anxious, worrying: “And if the oracle priests' prediction were to come true in some horrible way?
If the prince were to give up the world in all earnestness, what then?
We must heap upon him all that can intoxicate the senses: music, perfumes, silks, delicious food, beauty in every thing. I shall prevent him from renouncing the world!”
Hence, everyone at the palace did their utmost to entice the Bodhisattva with a whirl of sensual delights.
But for a second time, the prince asked for his carriage and headed toward the pleasure park.
En route, he saw a sick man, pale and wasted, whimpering in pain.
“Chandaka, what can have put this man in such a pitiful state?"
“He is ill, Sire.”
“This condition, can it affect me as well?”
“Prince, no living thing is immune from illness. Not you, not anyone."
They returned to the palace.
The prince kept repeating to himself: “So, no one is safe from falling ill, not even someone as fortunate as me!”
On his son's return, Shuddhodana decided to increase the number of amusements with which he had encircled Siddhartha.
But the prince again called for his carriage to go to the pleasure park.
And this time he saw villagers carrying a bier on which lay a body wrapped in a shroud.
A torch-bearer and a mob of people walked in front.
The bereaved family formed the tail end of the procession.
“What is this?” Siddhartha asked.
“My lord, this is what we call a corpse.”
“Will someone one day carry my stiffened body?”
“That is inevitable, my Lord.”
They returned to the palace.
“So. I canot escape death either. But then of what use is life?” wondered the prince.
“And what's the point of doubling or tripling the number of our courtly pleasures?”
The gods of the Pure Realm deliberated:
“This bodhisattva has many merits, certainly, but things depend also on circumstances or events.
We should encourage him to give up the world.”
They therefore made a shaven-headed renunciate, draped in saffron-colored cloth, and going to beg door to door, materialize.
Just as he had done thrice before, the Bodhisattva went riding off to the gardens along the river.
He noticed the mendicant in saffron carrying an alms bowl in one hand, and trudging slowly along.
“Chandaka, who is that man?”
“That man is a wise man who has given up worldly existence; he is a man who has mastered his mind.”
“Turn round, let's go back and speak to him!”
Chandaka did as he was told.
Once in the presence of the sage, the Bodhisattva fired off a volley of questions.
The saint explained the rules that govern a renunciate's life in detail.
“Now here's something excellent!” the Bodhisattva exclaimed; and then returned home.
“What a miracle!” he said to himself,

Sun of Faith - English: “this is precisely what I shall do: leave the palace and live like the itinerant mendicants who renounce the things of this world!”
The more he reflected upon this idea, the more his heart glowed with happiness.
